'''Tim Bergling'''{{efn|{{IPA|sv|ˈtɪmː ˈbæ̂rjlɪŋ|-|sv-Tim Bergling.ogg|small=no}}.}} (8 September 1989 – 20 April 2018), known professionally as '''Avicii''',{{efn|Pronounced {{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|v|iː|tʃ|i}} {{respell|ə|VEE|chee}} in English, {{IPA|sv|aˈvɪ̌tːɕɪ|}} in Swedish.}}<!-- Please do not add stylisations --> was a Swedish DJ, remixer, and record producer. At age 16, he began posting his [[remix]]es on electronic music forums, which led to his first record deal.<ref name=" Avicii obituary">{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/apr/22/avicii-obituary |title=Avicii obituary |last=McIver |first=Joel |date=22 April 2018 |work=The Guardian |access-date=22 April 2018 |archive-date=21 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180621171028/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/apr/22/avicii-obituary |url-status=live }}</ref> He rose to prominence in 2011 with his single "[[Levels (Avicii song)|Levels]]". His debut studio album, ''[[True (Avicii album)|True]]'' (2013), blended electronic music with elements of multiple genres and received generally positive reviews. It peaked in the top 10 in more than 15 countries and topped international charts;<ref>[https://www.australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Avicii&titel=True&cat=a Avicii – True] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170611060520/https://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Avicii&titel=True&cat=a |date=11 June 2017 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved 16 October 2015.</ref> the lead single, "[[Wake Me Up (Avicii song)|Wake Me Up]]", topped most music markets in Europe and reached number four in the United States.

In 2015, Bergling released his second studio album, ''[[Stories (Avicii album)|Stories]]'', and in 2017 he released an extended play, ''[[Avīci (01)]]''.<ref name="billboard.com">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7897874/avicii-new-ep-avici|title=Avicii Breaks Musical Silence With 'Avīci' EP: Listen|first=David|last=Rishty|date=10 August 2017|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=11 April 2023|archive-date=31 July 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180731032924/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7897874/avicii-new-ep-avici|url-status=live}}</ref> His catalog also included the singles "[[I Could Be the One (Avicii and Nicky Romero song)|I Could Be the One]]" with [[Nicky Romero]], "[[You Make Me]]", "[[X You]]", "[[Hey Brother]]", "[[Addicted to You (Avicii song)|Addicted to You]]", "[[The Days (Avicii song)|The Days]]", "[[The Nights (Avicii song)|The Nights]]", "[[Waiting for Love (Avicii song)|Waiting for Love]]", "[[Without You (Avicii song)|Without You]]", "[[Lonely Together (Avicii song)|Lonely Together]]" and "[[SOS (Avicii song)|SOS]]". Bergling was nominated for a [[Grammy Award]] for his work on "[[Sunshine (David Guetta song)|Sunshine]]" with [[David Guetta]] in 2012<ref name="Avicii">{{cite web|url=https://idolator.com/6097162/2012-grammy-nominations|title=Grammy Awards 2012|last=Avicii|access-date=23 May 2013|date=December 2011|archive-date=24 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524223320/https://idolator.com/6097162/2012-grammy-nominations|url-status=live}}</ref> and "Levels" in 2013. Several music publications credit Bergling as among the DJs who ushered electronic music into [[Top 40]] radio in the early 2010s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/celebrity_news/2018/04/avicii_s_hits_brought_electronic_dance_music_to_mainstream |title=Avicii's hits brought electronic dance music to mainstream |last=Gottlieb |first=Jed |date=21 April 2018 |work=[[Boston Herald]] |access-date=21 April 2018 |archive-date=1 December 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181201123248/https://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/celebrity_news/2018/04/avicii_s_hits_brought_electronic_dance_music_to_mainstream |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/top-dj-avicii-dead-at-28 |title=Top DJ Avicii dies at 28 |date=21 April 2018 |work=[[The Straits Times]] |access-date=21 April 2018 |archive-date=28 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210228011342/https://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/entertainment/top-dj-avicii-dead-at-28 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Bergling retired from touring in 2016, after several years of stress and poor mental health.<ref name="svtopenletter">{{cite web|date=26 April 2018|title=Aviciis familj i öppet brev: "Tim var inte gjord för det maskineri han hamnade i"|trans-title=Avicii's family in open letter: "Tim was not made for the machinery he ended up in"|url=https://www.svt.se/kultur/aviciis-familj-i-oppet-brev-han-orkade-inte-langre|url-status=live|access-date=2 February 2021|website=SVT Culture|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|language=sv|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180426194817/https://www.svt.se/kultur/aviciis-familj-i-oppet-brev-han-orkade-inte-langre |archive-date=26 April 2018 }}</ref> In 2018, he died by suicide while on holiday in [[Muscat]], Oman. His third and final album, ''[[Tim (Avicii album)|Tim]]'', was [[Posthumous publication|released posthumously]] in 2019.<ref name=":0" />

== Life and career ==
=== 1989–2010: Early life and career ===
Tim Bergling was born in [[Stockholm]] on 8 September 1989,<ref>{{Cite news |date=23 April 2018 |title=Avicii obituary |language=en |work=[[The Times]] |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/avicii-obituary-xqxhldpfg |access-date=9 March 2022 |issn=0140-0460 |archive-date=9 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220309002342/https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/avicii-obituary-xqxhldpfg |url-status=live }}</ref> the son of Klas Bergling, who ran an office supply business, and actress [[Anki Lidén]].<ref name=":6" /> He had three siblings: David Bergling, Linda Sterner, and actor [[Anton Körberg]]. He started mixing in his bedroom at the age of eight.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://planetradio.co.uk/metro/entertainment/music/13-facts-avicii-probably-know/|title=13 facts you probably didn't know about Avicii|date=16 August 2016|website=Metro Radio|language=en|access-date=21 March 2019|archive-date=21 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190321191400/https://planetradio.co.uk/metro/entertainment/music/13-facts-avicii-probably-know/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Inspired by his brother, who was also a DJ, he began making music at the age of 16,<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Marikar|first1=Sheila|title=The E.D.M. star Avicii dies too soon|url=https://www.newyorker.com/culture/postscript/the-edm-star-avicii-dies-too-soon|access-date=24 April 2018|magazine=The New Yorker|date=20 April 2018|archive-date=12 November 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211112170734/https://www.newyorker.com/culture/postscript/the-edm-star-avicii-dies-too-soon|url-status=live}}</ref> teaching himself to use a [[Software piracy|pirated]] copy of [[FL Studio]].<ref name=":6" /> In May 2007, Bergling signed on with the Dejfitts Plays label.<ref name="mtv">{{cite web |title=Avicii Bio | Avicii Career |url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/avicii/biography/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921091622/http://www.mtv.com/artists/avicii/biography/ |archive-date=21 September 2013 |access-date=16 October 2013 |publisher=MTV}}</ref> He was a member of the [[Laidback Luke]] Forums, where he refined his craft and, at times, demonstrated his distinct deep house style.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://turnupthebass.net/2014/04/30/laidbackluke-forum-where-are-they-now/|title=Laidback Luke Forum: Where Are They Now?|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519074924/http://turnupthebass.net/2014/04/30/laidbackluke-forum-where-are-they-now/|website=turnupthebass.net|archive-date=19 May 2014|date=30 April 2014}}</ref> By 2009 to 2010, Bergling was a prolific producer and was releasing music incredibly quickly. His remixes during this period were "Sound of Now", "Muja", "Ryu" and "Even". === Health ===
In January 2012, Bergling was hospitalised for 11 days in [[New York City]] with [[acute pancreatitis]] caused by excessive alcohol use.<ref name=":6"/><ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Bein|first1=Kat|title=Avicii's Health Struggles: A Timeline|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/8358621/avicii-health-timeline|magazine=Billboard|access-date=22 April 2018|archive-date=21 April 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180421223102/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/8358621/avicii-health-timeline|url-status=live}}</ref> Between 2012 and 2014, Bergling was prescribed [[opioid]]s for the pain caused by his pancreatitis, including [[OxyContin]] and [[Vicodin]], to which he developed an addiction. In 2014, Bergling underwent surgery and had both his [[Appendix (anatomy)|appendix]] and [[gallbladder]] removed. In 2015, Bergling entered a [[Drug rehabilitation|rehab]] facility, later announcing in March 2016 that he would be retiring from touring.<ref name=":6" /> In the 2017 documentary ''[[Avicii: True Stories]]'', directed by his close and longtime collaborator Levan Tsikurishvili, Bergling spoke about his physical and mental health struggles. The documentary depicts the pressure from his management to continue performing live in spite of his objections.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Halperin|first1=Shirley|title='Avicii: True Stories' Documentary Reveals Star DJ's Struggles With Health, Fame and Early Retirement (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2017/music/news/avicii-documentary-true-stories-director-interview-1202553567/|access-date=24 April 2018|work=Variety|date=11 September 2017|archive-date=1 February 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210201044738/https://variety.com/2017/music/news/avicii-documentary-true-stories-director-interview-1202553567/|url-status=live}}</ref>

Following his retirement, Bergling took up [[Transcendental Meditation|transcendental meditation]], which he credited with reducing his anxiety, and started seeing a therapist.<ref name=":7" />

High pressure from management and fans to continue touring and maintaining his public persona were cited as key reasons for his suicide, according to ''[[GQ]]''. In a statement from the article, "Bergling feared upsetting fans. He was sensitive to the 'flood of [[hate mail]]' after cancelled gigs."<ref name="BritishGQ" />

His manager, Arash Pournouri, admitted that he knew of Bergling's anxieties but refused to label them a problem of mental health. Furthermore, his management team only became aware of his painkiller addiction in November 2014. They staged two interventions for him, neither of which were successful. Pournouri rescheduled many shows in order for Bergling to recover in Stockholm. Having discovered his client's alcohol issues earlier, Pournouri set out to forbid his promoters from offering him alcohol, clearing out his minibar and focusing on his recovery. Problems worsened, however, when there was no crew to "keep tabs" on Bergling during his recuperation.<ref name="BritishGQ">{{Cite web|last=Ralston|first=William|date=25 September 2018|title=Who really killed Avicii?|url=https://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/who-really-killed-avicii|url-status=live|access-date=27 January 2021|website=[[GQ]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180926174133/https://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/who-really-killed-avicii |archive-date=26 September 2018 }}</ref> Pournouri met with Bergling's father Klas in 2014 to share concerns about Bergling's health.<ref name=":6"/>

Against his client's wishes, Pournouri claimed to have cancelled two more world tours, which would have added up to approximately US$2.9 million in profits.<ref name="BritishGQ"/>

===Music innovation===
Many artists in the EDM genre have cited Avicii as influences on their work, many of whom paid tribute to him after his death. [[Alan Walker (music producer)|Alan Walker]] and [[DubVision]] described him as an "icon" in [[Electronic dance music|EDM]].<ref>{{cite web |last=karsoowuttt |date=20 April 2018 |title=Martin Garrix, Avicii's Manager & Artists Around The World React To Avicii's Death |url=https://www.youredm.com/2018/04/20/artists-react-avicii-death/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190608231356/https://www.youredm.com/2018/04/20/artists-react-avicii-death/ |archive-date=8 June 2019 |access-date=8 June 2019 |website=Your EDM}}</ref> Norwegian DJ [[Kygo]] cited Avicii as "[his] biggest inspiration and the reason why [he] started making electronic music." === Museum ===
{{Main|Avicii Experience}}
On 9 June 2020, it was announced that an Avicii Tribute Museum would open in Stockholm in the summer of 2021.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Bain |first=Katie |date=9 June 2020 |title=Avicii Tribute Museum to Open in Stockholm in 2021 |url=http://www.billboard.com/amp/articles/news/dance/9398818/avicii-tribute-museum-opening-2021 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |language=en |access-date=12 August 2020 |archive-date=23 September 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200923132401/https://www.billboard.com/amp/articles/news/dance/9398818/avicii-tribute-museum-opening-2021 |url-status=live }}</ref> The renamed Avicii Experience was opened in February 2022 by [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Prince Carl Phillip]] and [[Princess Sofia, Duchess of Värmland|Princess Sofia]], alongside Bergling's father Klas, in Space Stockholm, a new digital culture centre near [[Sergels torg]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Yopko |first=Nick |title=Swedish Royalty Inaugurate the Avicii Experience Museum In Stockholm |url=https://edm.com/news/avicii-experience-museum-opening-february-2022 |access-date=10 March 2022 |website=EDM.com – The Latest Electronic Dance Music News, Reviews & Artists |date=25 February 2022 |language=en |archive-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310122340/https://edm.com/news/avicii-experience-museum-opening-february-2022 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="TimesMuseum">{{Cite news |last=Davies |first=Tracey |date=5 March 2022 |title=The winner takes it all: will Stockholm's Abba museum or Avicii experience triumph? |language=en |work=[[The Times]] |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/the-winner-takes-it-all-will-stockholms-abba-museum-or-avicii-experience-triumph-2rbjlrj9m |url-status=live |access-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20220305070752/https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/the-winner-takes-it-all-will-stockholms-abba-museum-or-avicii-experience-triumph-2rbjlrj9m |archive-date=5 March 2022 |issn=0140-0460}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Bain |first=Katie |date=25 February 2022 |title=Take a Tour of Stockholm's Newly Opened Avicii Experience Tribute Museum |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/avicii-museum-stockholm-avicii-experience-tribute-sweden-1235036135/ |access-date=10 March 2022 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US |archive-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310120836/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/avicii-museum-stockholm-avicii-experience-tribute-sweden-1235036135/ |url-status=live }}</ref> The museum features reconstructions of Bergling's childhood bedroom and Los Angeles mansion, as well as offering recordings of Avicii's most popular work and the ability to remix them, as well as unreleased music.<ref name=TimesMuseum />

The museum was the idea of Bergling's parents, who wanted to give fans a place to remember and celebrate the work of their late son and learn about his process for creating music. The interactive museum also includes exhibitions from various stages in Bergling's life, including a simulation of the high-paced lifestyle he experienced before his retirement from touring in 2016, which are designed to give visitors an understanding of the health issues faced by the star. Exhibitions are also dedicated to raising the awareness of mental health problems in young people and the wider music industry.<ref>{{Cite news |date=28 February 2022 |title=Avicii fans touched by 'emotional' museum in Stockholm |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-60557499 |access-date=10 March 2022 |archive-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310120812/https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-60557499 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last= |first= |title=Sweden honors star DJ Avicii with museum |url=https://www.dw.com/en/sweden-honors-star-dj-avicii-with-museum/a-60889922 |access-date=10 March 2022 |website=[[Deutsche Welle]] |language=en-GB |archive-date=10 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220310070601/https://www.dw.com/en/sweden-honors-star-dj-avicii-with-museum/a-60889922 |url-status=live }}</ref>
